text: 7506/1/18 REV 1 GW/st 1 TREE.2.B EN Council of the European Union Brussels, 24 July 2018 (OR. en) 7506/1/18 REV 1 ENER 110 ENV 200 CLIMA 55 COMPET 184 CONSOM 78 FISC 157 CODEC 444 Interinstitutional File: 2016/0380(COD) NOTE From: General Secretariat of the Council To: Delegations No. Cion doc.: 15150/1/16 REV 1 + ADD 1 REV 1 Subject: Proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on common rules for the internal market in electricity (recast) Delegations will find in the Annex the first revision of the four column document concerning the above-mentioned proposal. The revision includes Presidency compromise proposals as set out in the fourth column following delegations' comments and contributions as well as proper consideration of the discussions with the European Parliament held at technical level. The compromise proposals concern the following articles: • Articles 1, 3 - General provisions • Article 4 - Free choice of electricity supplier • Article 7 - Direct lines • Article 10 - Basic contractual rights • Article 11 - Entitlement to a dynamic electricity price contract • Article 12 - Right to switch and rules on switching-related fees • Article 13 – Aggregation contract

7506/1/18 REV 1 GW/st 2 TREE.2.B EN • Article 14 - Comparison tools • Article 15 - Active customers • Article 16 - Energy communities • Article 17 - Demand response through aggregation • Article 18 - Bills and billing information • Article 25 - Single point of contact • Article 26 - Right to out-of-court dispute settlement • ANNEX I • ANNEX II Furthermore, following the discussion on the subject of interconnectors in the Energy Working Party on 2 July 2018, the Presidency has developed a revised text on the definition of "interconnector" set out in the fourth column of Article 2(33), point 138. The proposed definition is based on the current definition of Directive 2009/72/EG, with the following refinements: - explicit restriction to transmission systems; - exclusion of transmission equipment crossing bidding zones inside a Member State (“internal interconnectors”); - clarification for network codes and guidelines applying to third countries in article 54 draft Electricity Regulation; see e.g. article 1 of Regulation 2015/1222 (CACM Guideline), article 1 of Regulation 2017/2195 (Balancing Guideline). The Presidency would welcome Member States' opinion on the suggested Presidency compromise texts set out in the fourth column. Based on this document and Member States feedback, the Presidency will prepare the revised mandate to be examined by Coreper on 7 September 2018. As regards the definition of “interconnector” the Presidency will prepare a proposal and invite Coreper to examine and reach an agreement with a view to establishing a general approach on this issue. Delegations are welcome to send their written comments till 24 August cob . ______________________

7506/1/18 REV 1 GW/st 22 ANNEX TREE.2.B EN 36. (22a) Shorter expected switching times can encourage consumers to search for better energy deals and switch suppliers. The increased deployment of information technology will mean that the technical switching process of registering a new supplier in a metering point at the market operator should typically be able to be completed within 24 hours on any working day by the year 2025. Notwithstanding other steps in the switching process that must be completed before the technical process of switching is initiated, ensuring the technical process of switching can take place within 24 hours by this date will minimise switching times, helping to increase consumer engagement and retail competition. In any case, the total duration of the switching process should not exceed three weeks from the date of the customer notification.

(23) Independent comparison tools including websites are an effective means for customers to assess the merits of different energy offers available on the market. Search costs are lower as they no longer need to collect information from individual suppliers and service providers. Such tools can provide the right balance between the need for information to be clear and concise and the need for it to be complete and comprehensive. They should aim at including the broadest possible range of available offers, and at covering the market as completely as is feasible so as to give the customer a representative overview.. It is crucial that the information given on such tools be trustworthy, impartial and transparent. (23) Independent comparison tools including websites are an effective means for smaller customers to assess the merits of different energy offers available on the market. Search costs are lower as they no longer need to collect information from individual suppliers and service providers. Such tools can provide the right balance between the need for information to be clear and concise and the need for it to be complete and comprehensive. They should aim at including the broadest possible range of available offers, and at covering the market as completely as is feasible so as to give the customer a representative overview. It is crucial that consumers have access to at least one comparison tool and that the information given on such tools be trustworthy, impartial and transparent. Member States may provide for this through a comparison tool that is operated by a national authority or a verified comparison tool that is operated by a private company.
